sentences.sentence: YOUR VIEW: Letters to the editor: our readers share their views.
Please send your letters toletters@independent.co.ukThere seems an avalanche of strong feelings against Rishi Sunak's foolish, not to say,unfeeling “bet” with Piers Morganand quite rightly too.
It shows just how low Sunak is prepared to stoop.The effort andtax money wastedon his doomed, vanity adventure would be better spent on improving the lot of the British people.

Surely our brokenNHS, failing economy or the plethora of other disasters caused by this incompetent government's 14 years of mismanagement, would benefit from an injection of cash.And to add to the woes of the Conservative Party there is yet another “family” vying inside the party -PopCon.
At the helm is thechief jester Liz Truss.

It beggars belief that she would dare to raise her head above the parapet, unlike Kwasi Kwarteng who, with slightly more dignity, has decided to call it a day and will not contest his seat at the next election.Flying a few hundred refugees to an unsafe country?
Rwanda is an absurd reaction to immigration, of which Mr Sunak must be well aware.
It certainly will not win votes and the Tories need to do much more to win the next election.
But their goose was cooked long ago.Keith PooleBasingstokeSunak is not engaging his brainI readJohn Rentoul's recent columnwith interest.

Why oh why did the prime minister not engage his brain first before utteringsuch a dire comment, especially asEsther Ghey was in theHouse of Commons?It was gut-wrenching andKeir Starmerhad every right to look incandescent with fury.

Of course, Sunak was on a roll with Labour's perceived U-turns and just could not stop his rhetoric at the most sensitive point, but as aprime minister that was exactlywhat he should have done.Also, you do not devalue such an important issue as the Rwanda deportation plan to the lowest common denominator ina bet with Piers Morgan.
To be scrupulously fair, I think he was caught out in the moment, but his answer should have been a stern look and emphasis that this is too serious a situation for such a crass action.
I think the government will be aghast at all this mayhem and damage limitation.

The Tory machine will no doubt go into overdrive, to try and rescue what is probably an irrecoverable situation.Judith A DanielsNorfolkNo decent prime minister would act like thisWhen Rishi Sunak used PMQs yesterday to make “jokes” at the expense oftransgender people, at the very moment when the mother of a murdered transgender schoolgirl was in the House of Commons, it underlined two things about the prime minister.Firstly,he is tone-deaf,and unable to think on his feet.
The trans jibe had been written into his rambling speech, and he wastoo incompetent to leave itout.Secondly, he's callous and unpleasant.

No decent prime minister who supposedly governs for all would lower themselves at the dispatch box by mocking a targeted group.Sebastian MonblatSurbitonLabour can't get scared nowAbandoning part or the whole of Labour's£28bn green energy planwill dismay and mystify many of its supporters across the country.Dismay because it has offered the most radical and sustainable plan of the major political parties to meet the UK's decarbonisation targets while stimulating growth with newer cleaner industries.

Mystifying as it departs from the course many developed economies have already successfully taken.No doubt the Liz Truss “mini Budget” debacle has spooked the leadership, but this is more about prudent investment than profligate spending and besides other high debt and high deficit ratios to GDPs such as the US and Japan have not prevented them from making what are paradigm shifts in their economies to meet the growing climate menace.Paul DolanCheshire

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
documents.inputText: YOUR VIEW : Letters to the editor: our readers share their views. Please send your letters toletters@independent.co.ukThere seems an avalanche of strong feelings against Rishi Sunak’s foolish, not to say,unfeeling “bet” with Piers Morganand quite rightly too. It shows just how low Sunak is prepared to stoop.The effort andtax money wastedon his doomed, vanity adventure would be better spent on improving the lot of the British people. Surely our brokenNHS, failing economy or the plethora of other disasters caused by this incompetent government’s 14 years of mismanagement, would benefit from an injection of cash.And to add to the woes of the Conservative Party there is yet another “family” vying inside the party –PopCon.  At the helm is thechief jester Liz Truss.  It beggars belief that she would dare to raise her head above the parapet, unlike Kwasi Kwarteng who, with slightly more dignity, has decided to call it a day and will not contest his seat at the next election.Flying a few hundred refugees to an unsafe country? Rwanda is an absurd reaction to immigration, of which Mr Sunak must be well aware. It certainly will not win votes and the Tories need to do much more to win the next election. But their goose was cooked long ago.Keith PooleBasingstokeSunak is not engaging his brainI readJohn Rentoul’s recent columnwith interest. Why oh why did the prime minister not engage his brain first before utteringsuch a dire comment, especially asEsther Ghey was in theHouse of Commons?It was gut-wrenching andKeir Starmerhad every right to look incandescent with fury. Of course, Sunak was on a roll with Labour’s perceived U-turns and just could not stop his rhetoric at the most sensitive point, but as aprime minister that was exactlywhat he should have done.Also, you do not devalue such an important issue as the Rwanda deportation plan to the lowest common denominator ina bet with Piers Morgan.  To be scrupulously fair, I think he was caught out in the moment, but his answer should have been a stern look and emphasis that this is too serious a situation for such a crass action. I think the government will be aghast at all this mayhem and damage limitation. The Tory machine will no doubt go into overdrive, to try and rescue what is probably an irrecoverable situation.Judith A DanielsNorfolkNo decent prime minister would act like thisWhen Rishi Sunak used PMQs yesterday to make “jokes” at the expense oftransgender people, at the very moment when the mother of a murdered transgender schoolgirl was in the House of Commons, it underlined two things about the prime minister.Firstly,he is tone-deaf,and unable to think on his feet. The trans jibe had been written into his rambling speech, and he wastoo incompetent to leave itout.Secondly, he’s callous and unpleasant. No decent prime minister who supposedly governs for all would lower themselves at the dispatch box by mocking a targeted group.Sebastian MonblatSurbitonLabour can’t get scared nowAbandoning part or the whole of Labour’s£28bn green energy planwill dismay and mystify many of its supporters across the country.Dismay because it has offered the most radical and sustainable plan of the major political parties to meet the UK’s decarbonisation targets while stimulating growth with newer cleaner industries. Mystifying as it departs from the course many developed economies have already successfully taken.No doubt the Liz Truss “mini Budget” debacle has spooked the leadership, but this is more about prudent investment than profligate spending and besides other high debt and high deficit ratios to GDPs such as the US and Japan have not prevented them from making what are paradigm shifts in their economies to meet the growing climate menace.Paul DolanCheshire
